Award.AwardTitle: 2019 Graduate Climate Conference; Woods Hole, Massachusetts; November 7-10, 2019
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the 13th Graduate Climate Conference (GCC), held 7-10 November 2019 at the Marine Biological Laboratory of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute. The conference has been held annually and alternates between Woods Hole and the Pack Forest Center of the University of Washington.

The GCC is an interdisciplinary climate conference organized by and for graduate students. It provides a discussion forum for students conducting research on climate in a variety of disciplines including atmospheric dynamics, ocean dynamics, ocean biology and chemistry, atmospheric chemistry, climate dynamics, paleoclimate, and human dimensions of climate variability and change. The meeting is intended to help students familiarize themselves with the breadth of climate science, gain exposure to the enormous range of tools available to address climate-related questions, and understand how their research fits into the broader landscape of current climate science. The conference seeks to better prepare graduate students for scientific inquiry in a field that increasingly demands interdisciplinary approaches. Funds provided here support travel and subsistence for 80 students chosen through a competitive process which places emphasis on selecting a cross-section of applicants that reflects the diversity of the next generation of scientists

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Graduate Climate Conferences (GCC) has been running for 13 years to provide an opportunity for climate science graduate students to share their findings, meet potential future collaborators, and develop new professional skills. The single-session, graduate-student-only format (no senior scientists attend the GCC) provides an inclusive and supportive space for scientific discussions, while also exposing students to a broad array of climate science subfields. 
This proposal partly supported the13th GCC held from November 8-10, 2019 at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts. Thanks to increased funding from NSF, a record-breaking 115 students attended, representing dozens of states and several countries. The GCC 2019 committee made a concerted effort to improve the diversity and inclusivity of the conference. In contrast to most other academic conferences, the majority of attendees (>50%) were women, as were the oral presenters (65%) and follow-up question askers (54%).
All attendees presented their research, either in one of the ten oral talk sessions (3-4 talks each) or three poster sessions. In addition to the traditional core oral sessions on atmosphere, ocean, and climate dynamics, this year’s conference featured presentations on diverse topics such as the engineering of climate solutions, the politics of climate activism, and the philosophy of climate modelling. The session topics at GCC 2019 were: Paleoclimate, Earth, and Planetary History; Climate Models and Projections; Oceanography; Ice; Policy and Action; Paleoclimate and Deep Time; Atmospheric Science and Meteorology; Biogeochemistry and Ecology; Localized Climates; Impacts and Mitigation.
The inclusion of social sciences in the program, a novelty of this year, helped address the disconnect between the physical sciences and the social avenues which hinders progress on climate action. In addition to research presentations, the GCC offered professional development opportunities via a Keynote lecture and a few workshops, which focused on effective strategies for communicating climate science using various media: radio, fiction writing, and political advocacy. Student leaders in geoscience-specific diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts also hosted a workshop for attendees to share personal experiences and strategies for advancing these issues in their own institutions. By providing hands-on training in science communication, the GCC helped students learn how to apply their research beyond academics and communicate their science effectively to diverse audiences.
